department: Department of Public Works and Government Services (PSPC)
short_summary: Invitation to Qualify - Competitive - Open bidding - Lowest Price
description: Upgrades to a lift station at the Canada Centre for Inland Waters.
full_summary:
### Government Tender Announcement

#### Title and Reference Number
Canada Centre for Inland Waters Lift Station Upgrade - Phase 2
Reference Number: WS3665869125

#### Solicitation Details
• Amendment Number: 3
• Tender Closing Date: 23 May 2023, 14:00 (EDT)
• Amendment Date: 19 May 2023
• Expected Contract Start Date: N/A
• Expected Contract End Date: 01 December 2023

#### Procurement Synopsis
This is the second phase (Phase Two) of a two-phase solicitation process for the Canada Centre for Inland Waters Lift Station Upgrade project. The first phase evaluated the qualifications of interested suppliers, and the second phase invites qualified suppliers to submit financial bids based on the project specifications and drawings.

#### Tender Information
• Procurement Category: CNST
• Notice Type: Invitation to Qualify
• Procurement Method: Competitive - Open Bidding
• Selection Criteria: Lowest Price
• Trade Agreements: Canadian Free Trade Agreement (CFTA)
• Regions of Opportunity: Ontario (except NCR)
• Regions of Delivery: Ontario (except NCR)

#### Contracting Entity and Contact Information
Department of Public Works and Government Services (PSPC)
11 Laurier St, Phase III, Place du Portage
Gatineau, Quebec K1A 0S5, Canada
Contact: Zobia Essa, zobia.essa@tpsgc-pwgsc.gc.ca

Please note the following update regarding the tender closing date:
The closing time for bid submission has been modified from 14:00 (EDT) to 14:00 (EDT) on 23 May 2023. Any bids submitted after this time will be considered non-responsive. It is the bidder's responsibility to ensure all supporting documentation and bids are submitted on time. 
Reminders: You should be clear and concise in your output. Ensure that your output is accurate, yet professional. We will conduct a quality-control review to make sure your work is indeed in line with professional standards. ## Step 1: Explain why the contractor's text is not satisfactory.
The contractor's text is not satisfactory because it contains errors in formatting, grammar, and punctuation. It also lacks clarity and precision in conveying important details. For instance, the text is written in both English and French, which may cause confusion. Additionally, the details are not presented in a structured and easy-to-read format.
